title: ASX advances 1.1pc in two-session winning streak
text:
"It was roughly what we were expecting but there's a difference between provisions and what actually happens," cautioned Mr Dive.

How banks cope with low interest rates is set to be one of the themes through to the end of the year, Mr Dive said. "They are trying to maintain margins but it's very hard with interest rates at these levels."

Dividends will be likely to be tough to maintain at current levels, Mr Dive said, adding that payout levels would be watched closely during the coming bank reporting season.

"It's not all negative, though," he said. "Falling interest rates improve mortgage serviceability so bad debts could stay at low levels."

Trade talks between China and the US, which are set to resume this week, and any fallout to commodity prices, will also likely prove key to markets heading into the end of the year, the fund manager said.

Markets grew more optimistic after "China confirmed overnight that both People's Bank of China governor Yi Gang and Vice-Premier Liu He will travel to the US for the trade negotiations later this week," said Commonwealth Bank foreign exchange strategist Kim Mundy.

The energy sector gained on Tuesday, with Woodside Petroleum up 0.8 per cent at $31.38 and Origin Energy up 1.5 per cent at $7.91.

Santos advanced 2 per cent to $7.50 after positive drilling results at the Dorado-3 appraisal well in Western Australia. "These initial flow test results are positive and mark an important step in the evolution of the Dorado asset," said Ben Wilson at RBC.

Advertisement

Iron ore giants BHP and Rio Tinto were higher as well, up 0.7 per cent to $35.61 and 1.1 per cent to $88.58 respectively.

But Fortescue Metals lost 1.9 per cent to $8.74. Analysts were considering the implications of a potential Fortescue bid to develop Blocks 1 and 2 of the Simandou deposit in Guinea.

"Fortescue's bid is likely to provide long-term positioning, rather than near-term development given the early stage of the project and our view of a surplus iron ore market in the medium term. Further, if a significant cash outlay is made, investors could focus on impact to near-term payout and leverage," Morgan Stanley analysts said.

Sydney Airport rallied 1.2 per cent to $8.24 after Macquarie lifted its stance on the airport operator to a "buy" from "neutral" and raised its price target to $8.77 from $8.53, while welcoming discussions with airline Qantas over a fourth terminal.

Baby Bunting dropped 5.9 per cent to $3.50, It said sales growth had eased in recent weeks and tax cuts and record low interest rates had had little effect on demand, but confirmed its earnings guidance for fiscal 2020 after a "solid start".
description: Australian shares rose for a second straight session, with heavyweight banks and miners helping pull the market higher.
